First View: £100m UK Restructuring, First Move Towards US Only Business?

11:12 am

BE

Conclusion: FY16 results in line, but further restructuring in the UK (£100m) and a review
of the Nordic business could mean the first steps towards a US only business. LFL growth so
far this year FY17 is 1.5% at Group level and 4.5% in the US, broadly in line with our forecasts.

BE

Detail: A £100m (£70m cash) restructuring programme has been announced in the UK,
resulting in 80 branch closures and 850 job losses. The programme will take 2-3 years and
should generate £25-30m of cost savings when complete. With a further strategic review
underway in the Nordics we believe this represents the first move towards a US/North
American only business over the medium/long term. The US Industrial market remains weak (-10%) and the outlook statement mixed, citing an uncertain economic environment in
some markets and continued price deflation.

BE

Current company consensus for FY17 EBITA stands at £1052m, implying
c.14% YonY growth. Given the weak support from the top line we think this
could be challenging even with the benefit of FX. Like many US dominated UK
stocks, dollar earnings have not been increasing but the shares have been
going up on FX upgrades and also some re-rating. We think these stocks are
pricing upgrades which we find difficult to see in a slowing macro
environment. The stock currently trades on 12m fwd earnings of 15x vs. 12.5x
at the all time peak of US construction and sub 10x in a slowdown. We are
cautious on the outlook for the US and remain cautious on Wolseley. HOLD.

11:16 am
BE

And Davy.

BE

Wolseley’s final quarter results are behind expectations and
might be described as underwhelming. It is clear that the US
business continues to perform strongly despite a somewhat
challenging backdrop. However, beyond the US, there is little
growth or opportunity to generate excitement. The
restructuring programme detailed for the UK and a similar
exercise now to be completed in the Nordic region confirms
this. The group’s balance sheet remains strong. The lack of a
share buyback programme for now should be viewed positively
in our view, supporting growing expectations that WOS can re-
accelerate its inorganic growth strategy. The stock has
materially outperformed the broader UK distribution peer
group since the outcome of the EU referendum. As such, we see
little upside from current levels.

PM

Interim results are well ahead of expectations leading to c10% EPS upgrades this year and more than 20% in the outer years. The benefits from the enhanced management team, investment in systems, IT, physical infrastructure and analytical tools have led to a continuation of the dynamic growth being driven from a flexible approach to driving customer acquisition led growth. With KPI’s indicating higher ASP’s, more items per basket as well as frequency rates improving, one should take confidence that this update/results bode well for future growth. While risks remain with any high growth business, we feel Boohoo’s disruptive credentials, high margins and distinctive inventory and brand led strategy is clearly a structural winner. We maintain Buy and increase our TP slightly ahead of our forecast upgrades to 120p, noting 24% upside.

PM

Making a comparison to ASOS is logical and at first glance both companies look up with events trading on PE multiples to CY 2017E of 56x and 45x respectively. However on a PEG basis this is 1.75x for ASOS falling rapidly to 1.3x by Dec 2018E and for Boohoo a somewhat more accomodating 1.2x by Dec 2017E. While we forecast Boohoo to generate sales growth higher than ASOS, our profit growth forecasts are slightly more modest due to higher depreciation reflecting the cycle of investment currently underway.

In perspective, and considering growth rates, we feel the shares do not fully underscore the scale of the opportunity

Trading continues to go from strength to strength as boohoo again reports
impressive growth of 40% over the H117 period, ahead of our expectations
of 33%. In addition to top line growth, there has been improvement in all KPIs,
driven primarily by an optimised mix of marketing, price and promotional
activity. This has delivered operational leverage and resulted in EPS growth
of 124%. The boohoo brand has strong momentum both in the UK and
internationally, and coupled with continued investment in operational
improvements and technology as well as international expansion, we believe
will continue to deliver significant profitable growth.

on an earnings basis, and we feel there is scope for the share price to continue
to move higher as the company continues to gather market share and
demonstrate the strengths of the business model.

easyJet plc (EZJ:LSE): Last: 1,003, down 13 (-1.28%), High: 1,020, Low: 998.50, Volume: 1.31m
BE

Which UBS is selling ahead of results.

11:35 am
BE

6 October full year trading update is next catalyst before November results
We think after two profit warnings over the last c3 months the risk to 2016 consensus
earnings expectations are broadly neutral with 2016e PBT consensus forecasts in the
range of £475m to £596m. Nevertheless, we have slightly reduced our estimates for
2016e (previous £541m) on the back of currency movements and are now on 2016e
PBT of £524m compared to consensus £530m. Looking into 2017 visibility
unsurprisingly remains poor with uncertainties around winter pricing. Nevertheless, we
see risk on the downside given industry capacity indications.

BE

2017 forecast EPS reduced c10% on back of currency outlook
We reduce our 2017 forecasts mainly on the currency change to forecasts (pound
weakness will weigh into cost base). In terms of drivers of 2017e earnings we assume
reported fares down c6% reported and ex fuel unit costs that are broadly flat (in line
with company guidance). Our 2017e PBT is now £481m versus our previous forecast
£534m. We think Q1 will be challenging given the revenue base effect. Furthermore,
have also made earnings changes beyond 2017e but acknowledge that visibility is low.

BE

In short term now is not the time in our view to buy the shares
We think the risk to consensus 2017e earnings remains on the downside with our
2017e net income forecast c11% below consensus. Until industry short haul capacity
discipline returns we think it is difficult for the market to establish the true earnings
floor for the industry. However, for those with a time frame extending beyond the next
12 months, we acknowledge that easyJet could look more attractive given the
structural growth characteristics and one of the industry leading positions.

11:35 am
BE

Valuation: Maintain Neutral rating but reduce PT to £10.7 (previous £11.5)
While risk to earnings remains on the downside we see limited interest from investors
with a near term focus. We continue to value the shares on 6.2x 2017e EV/Ebitdar
which provides our new £10.70 (previous £11.50). We retain our Neutral rating.

BE

11:37 am
BE

Here's Barclays.

BE

After what has been a challenging year with disruptive geopolitical events, Brexit and material FX moves, Thomas Cook’s pre-close statement this morning is rather uneventful. The company made no change to guidance and guides to delivering FY16 EBIT of ‘around £300m’ (vs. Barclays £297m and Bloomberg £302m). This is inclusive of an FX tailwind of £37-38m vs. Barclays estimate of £35m. The previous guidance of ‘around £300m’ was inclusive of a £32m FX tailwind, so the company has benefitted from a c. £5m benefit from FX since Q3 results. The company stated that trading for the summer 2016 programme closed as expected and that sales for the Winter 2016/17 season are in line YoY. Looking at Winter trading, trends are somewhat unchanged with solid performance from the UK and Northern Europe and weak demand from Continental Europe (especially Germany and Belgium). Whilst the company stated that trading for the Summer 2017 programme is encouraging with customers booking early to secure holidays, only c. 10% of the summer programme is sold so far, so it is too early to read much into trading yet, in our view. So overall, a solid statement with few material changes but a slightly positive tone for trading next year (albeit it is early days). We think this statement has a positive read-across to our preferred name, TUI which is due to release a pre-close trading statement tomorrow too. TCG’s CY17E P/E of 6.5x, (c.20% discount to LT average) and FCY yield of 16% make TCG shares appear very cheap vs. history and the sector. Risks remain: 1) visibility of earnings is low: with increased geopolitical risks, intense competition, seasonal cash flows and low margins, earnings volatility can be high. 2) UK volumes could soften given sterling depreciation vs. the euro and Brexit concerns. 3) Longer-term pressure from OTAs and Airbnb could lower demand.

BE

And Goldman.

11:37 am
BE

Summer 2016 trends are broadly unchanged: bookings down 4% yoy (-5%
at July), and pricing deteriorated to -4% (-3% at July) as the group
continued to discount to recover lost volumes from currency movements
and ongoing geopolitical events. UK trading improved slightly with
bookings +1% (-1% as at July) and prices -5% (-4% at July), while in
Northern Europe trading remains soft due to capacity adjustments and
tough comps (bookings -6% and prices +3%). Overcapacity in the airline
market and weak consumer demand due to geopolitics (especially for
Turkey holidays) continue to impact trading in Continental Europe
(bookings: -9%, pricing: -3%) and Airlines Germany, where trading remains
challenging and pressures into 4Q16 have not eased (implying break-even
for FY16, GSe EBIT £8 mn).

BE

We see downside risk to FY17 consensus (GSe EBIT of £290 mn, 13% below)
driven by weakening consumer confidence and continued airline capacity
growth (4Q16E +6-8% yoy). The stock trades on 8.6x CY17E P/E and a FCF
yield of 4.8%, which we view as unattractive, given weak cash conversion to
deliver the turnaround, and no organic revenue growth. Our 12m price target
is 57p, based on 10% CY18E FCFy discounted back by 12%. Key risks: fasterthan-
expected fall in unemployment/recovery in EU consumer demand,
exceptional cash costs, any disposal of/strategic action involving Condor.

BE

Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 208.00, down 1.75 (-0.83%), High: 211.25, Low: 205.65, Volume: 15.36m

11:50 am
BE

Lower targeted unit costs for copper, zinc and nickel as well as a mark to market for
coking coal in 2H16 are the main drivers behind our EBITDA revisions. At the half-year
stage management guided copper costs 8% lower for 2016, zinc costs 33% lower and
nickel costs 7% lower. We have also marked to market for the recent surge in coking coal
prices to above US$200/t, vs our 2H16 forecast of closer to US$100/t. Overall, these
two sets of changes account for 83% of our 11% increase to 2016 EBITDA to US$9.4bn.
We have also bumped our 2017 EBITDA forecast up by 3% to US$11.3bn.

BE

Our EPS forecast for 2016 has almost doubled to USc11/share, from USc6/share, while
our 2017 EPS forecast is up 7% to USc16/share. With unchanged forecasts for the
reinstatement of dividends in 2017 and 2018, we now forecast a dividend payout ratio
averaging 40-50% over the coming two years. This is the equivalent of a 3-5% dividend
yield at current share price levels.

BE

As always, however, the balance sheet will remain in focus for GLEN. We now forecast
net debt some 5-7% lower than we did previously over the coming 18 months, with
our revised 2016 net debt forecast at US$16.9bn and our 2017 net debt forecast at
US$14.5bn. We forecast GLEN to reach its medium-term net debt target of US$15bn
around mid 2017.

11:50 am
BE

On our revisions, GLEN should be able to return a double-digit free cash flow yield of
just over 10% by the end of 2017 and closer to 14-15% by 2018. However, on other key
metrics GLEN's ROIC should remain single digit through 2018, and retain a P/E multiple
which is a premium to the sector due the structure of its balance sheet and P&L.

BE

We have rolled out our GLEN valuation to year-end 2017 (15 months out) and revised
our multiples accordingly. Our EV/EBITDA multiple of 7.0x and 1.0x multiple for NPV are
both reflective of sector average multiples for mid-cycle valuations. We have given GLEN
a 10% premium to the sector P/E multiple to reflect the differentiated structure of its
P&L. On this basis, we revise our target price up 2% to 220p/share, in line with our 2017
EBITDA revision.

BE

Late last week GLEN reached a recent high of 212p/share, which is the closest the stock
has traded to our target price this year. With GLEN now pricing in closer to USc240/lb
copper (in line with other Hold rated copper stocks in our universe), we downgrade to a
HOLD rating. With less than 5% potential upside to our target from highs reached last
week, we would be cautious in building new positions in GLEN above this level.

11:51 am

The Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS) is a type of epilepsy with multiple different types of seizures, particularly tonic (stiffening) and atonic (drop) seizures. Intellectual development is usually, but not always, impaired.

BE

BE

BE

11:59 am
BE

Second LGS trial succeeds, with Epidiolex showing similar efficacy to the first
LGS trial. Yesterday, GW Pharma reported results from the second Phase 3
study of Epidiolex in Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome (LGS). The patients enrolled in
the trial had highly refractory disease, taking an average of three anti-epileptic
drugs (AEDs) concurrently, and having failed 7 previously. These patients had a
baseline seizure frequency of 85/month. During the treatment period, patients
taking Epidiolex 20mg/kg per day (n=76) on top of their current therapy achieved
a median reduction in monthly drop seizures of 42% compared with a reduction
of 17% in patients taking placebo (n=76), resulting in a 25% statistically significant
treatment effect (p=0.0047). Patients taking Epidiolex 10mg/kg per day (n=73)
achieved a median reduction in monthly drop seizures of 37% compared with a
reduction of 17% in patients taking placebo, a statistically significant treatment
effect of 20% (p=0.0016). As a reminder, Epidiolex demonstrated a reduction in
drop seizures of 44% vs. 22% for placebo in the first Phase 3 LGS study reported
in June

BE

Safety for Epidiolex appears consistent with prior trials and the ongoing
expanded access program. AEs were recorded in 84% of patients treated at
10mg/kg (89% of which were mild/moderate), 94% of patients in the 20mg/kg
group (88% mild/moderate), and 72% of placebo patients. The most common
(greater than 10%) AEs across dose groups included somnolence, decreased appetite,
diarrhea, and upper respiratory tract infection. Additionally, in the 20mg/kg
group there were common reports of pyrexia, vomiting and nasopharyngitis. One
potential concern is the status epilepticus experienced by at least 10% of
patients in the 10mg/kg group. Although no cases of status epilepticus were
deemed treatment related, we continue to monitor these developments. SAEs
were found in 13 patients in the 10mg/kg group (2 treatment related), 13 patients
in the 20mg/kg group (5 treatment related) and 8 patients receiving placebo.
There was one discontinuation due to AEs in the 10mg/kg group, 6 in the
20mg/kg group and one in placebo. No deaths occurred during the study, and
99% of completers opted into an open label extension trial

BE

Updating our model to reflect incremental de-risking; increasing our probability
of success for Epidiolex to 85% in Dravet and LGS, and our PT to $160. Given
the positive data from the second Phase 3 study in LGS, we have increased our
probability of success (POS) for Epidiolex in both LGS and Dravet Syndrome to
85%, increased our POS in tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) to 65% from 60%,
and increased our POS for off-label indications to 75%. We have also updated
our launch timing estimate based on the company’s plan to submit an NDA for
both indications in 1H17, assuming the maximum 90 days for DEA scheduling, and
now model Epidiolex launch in FY2018. As a reminder, GW Pharma maintains a
September fiscal year end. With these changes, our GWPH PT increases to $160
per share.

12:00 pm
BE

As focus shifts to commercialization, we continue to believe our launch
assumptions for Epidiolex are achievable, based on demand for Onfi, increased
pricing power, and high physician/patient awareness. Based on the results of
external consultations and our June 2015 AlphaWise survey of US and EU
pediatric neurologists (see our initiation note here), we believe that awareness of
Epidiolex is extremely high among both physicians and patients, bolstered by the
company's ongoing expanded access program, which as of Aug 1 included
approximately 500 patients across 32 U.S. clinical sites. We expect awareness
and demand for Epidiolex to exceed that of Lundbeck's Onfi, a benzodiazepine
with relatively little awareness outside of the medical community and a label
only for LGS. An analysis of IMS Health demand data for Onfi suggests our
forecast for Epidiolex may be conservative, showing a current run rate of
approximately ~35k script per month for Onfi vs. our launch model showing
~30k patients receiving Epidiolex near the same launch timepoint (see Exhibit 2
and Exhibit 3 below). We also anticipate that many of the patients enrolled in the
EAP will convert to paid scripts, fueling the early launch. Lastly, we also expect
Epidiolex to command premium pricing vs. Onfi, modeling net pricing of ~$32k per
year at launch vs. implied Onfi net pricing of ~$10k today in the U.S. Importantly,
Epidiolex is likely to receive a broad label for refractory patients, opening the
door for usage prior to Onfi, as an alternative to Onfi, or in conjunction
with/after Onfi. For these reasons, we believe Epidiolex is well-positioned for
commercial success.

BE

While the bear thesis has been largely disproven, GWPH could see volatility
into the formal data presentation. We note that the bear thesis for GWPH has
historically focused around questions regarding the efficacy and safety profile of
Epidiolex, and whether the drug has a treatment effect on seizure frequency
either alone or in combination with other AEDs. With the successful read-out of
the third placebo-controlled Phase 3 trial, we believe a significant part of the
bear thesis has been disproven, as Epidiolex has consistently shown a statistically
significant, clinically meaningful reduction in seizure frequency in highly
refractory populations. However, with very little topline data provided for key
secondary endpoints like the responder analysis, we note there may be some
volatility into the full dataset presentation expected at AES in December. At this
meeting we will also focus on the distribution of responses, the percentage of
patients worsening, the status epilepticus rate, the full safety profile and the
rate of responders in non-Onfi patients. Importantly, we think efficacy, rates of
response and safety/tolerability in the real world are likely to exceed that seen in
the trials, as clinicians are likely to dose titrate patients individually.

BE

Or, for the counterpoint, Janey.
